awd_titl_txt: Toward a Practice Driven and Co-Produced Urban Sustainability Research and Action Network (US-RAN)
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a grant to support a Sustainable Urban Systems (SUS) workshop. The workshop is designed to facilitate interaction between urban scholars and practitioners, and reinforce a foundation for holistic urban sustainability action. This workshop is to be driven by urban practitioners, informed by urban scholars, and grounded in existing and emerging real-world urban sustainability challenges. It will bring together urban sustainability practitioner networks and research networks to build a joint actionable research agenda for urban sustainability transformation. 

This actionable research agenda will apply the principles of co-production to incorporate new and existing knowledge from scientific, experiential, and indigenous sources to directly confront the challenge of urban sustainability transformations, all while remaining grounded in the needs of practitioners. This co-produced agenda, and integrating its ideas into active networks, research, and teaching initiatives, is targeted to to support movement towards sustainable urban systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Despite decades of research on and research funding intended to generate sustainability solutions, the relationships between university-based research on sustainability and the generation of positive sustainability outcomes in the real-world remains weak. To more deeply understand this concern and begin finding solutions to address it, this NSF supported workshop brought together 32 urban sustainability practitioners with 18 researchers and liaisons from federal agencies to build a joint agenda for urban sustainability transformation. Over the course of 2.5 days, participants collaborated to build a co-produced research agenda for the next generation of urban sustainability research at the NSF. The recommendations provided are also relevant for other federal, state, and philanthropic entities looking to invest in sustainability research, science, or practice.

More specifically, over the course of this 2.5 day workshop, participants provided detailed recommendations related to a potential NSF Sustainable Urban Systems Research Network (SUS RN) solicitation, including recommendations on the process by which the SUS RN could be administered to make it more equitable, how to more holistically and equitably evaluate broader impacts and principal investigator qualifications, and shifts in whose voice is prioritized on proposal evaluation panels. In addition, participants co-developed a set of key sustainability research themes to be addressed in the SUS RN, including: 1) urban sustainability within, across, and beyond the city; 2) infrastructure transformations; 3) disruptive structural and institutional changes; and 4) capacity building for city-university-community-based organization partnerships.  

Participants also developed a set of overarching principles for any future federal, state, or philanthropic investment opportunity related to urban or local sustainability. These three principles are heavily grounded in the lived experience of sustainability professionals and informed by the research experience of academic partners. The three principles are: 1) people first; 2) co-production; and 3) operationalizing equity. More details about each principle, including specific recommendations on how to operationalize them, can be found in the final workshop report. Overall, workshop participants emphasized that these principles are not solely relevant to the NSF SUS RN but are transferable to any program looking to invest in progress towards more equitable, just, and sustainable urban systems.

Finally, workshop participants provided guidance on promising ways to form collaborative practitioner-researcher partnerships to see research in these areas not only advanced, but co-produced, and used to inform real-world action.
